Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2014 05:03AM Obxflygirl1 wrote: Another UNC patient here. I drove 4 1/2 hours for treatment from the outer banks and would do it again in a heartbeat.  You will be in good hands.  I just got back from my 2 year check up.  Let us know if we can answer any questions for you. Take someone with you to take notes. I missed a lot of what was said that first day.  Hugs on this journey....
Posts.Title: No good news here either pugsnotdrugs Hopeful82014

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2013 08:20PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: yes, yes, yes......most of us have a meltdown or several along the way. I thought I was doing so well and then wow, out of the blue I was an emotional wreck 6 months after diagnosis. Meds and a couple therapy sessions helped so much. It was a relief to have my fears for the future validated. I'm a year out now and for the most part things are getting back to normal. Allow yourself time to grieve and process everything. Reach out and accept the help offered. It was hard for me to do this, but once I did, I knew it was the right thing to do and it helped with the emotional healing I so needed. Will be thinking of you.......
Posts.Title: Meltdown today cathy1955 pipers_dream

They see these things every day. Any mass would concern me enough to get a second opinion. Good luck and keep us posted, please

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2016 02:41PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: I'm assuming you aren't working so no social life there. Can you reach out to a local church? There are usually retired people who would be willing to spend time with you or assist you. Don't be afraid to ask. Take care and glad you are rid of the dog doo. Your mom ...I don't know what to say
Posts.Title: Very alone, very sad, very scared butterfly2b2016 Sunnyone22

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2015 06:23AM Obxflygirl1 wrote: so sorry for your mother and what your family is going through. My understanding is that Stage IV is considered when the cancer metasticises to another part of the body. I.e. Bones, liver brain, lungs. Having cancer in the nodes can be Stage 2 -3. I'm no expert but I agree with above post. Seek treatment at a teaching hospital ASAP. Hang in there. You will find so much support and valuable information on BC.org
Posts.Title: Stage 4 : confused and devastated mawerickin Heidihill

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2013 10:20AM Obxflygirl1 wrote: So.....did they byopsy the tissue right then? It took mine 5 days to get results. Once you have a plan, with the tumor staging and see the "right" doctor, you will feel better...I promise you that. Ask any questions here...also get a notebook to ask questions of the doctor. Make sure your husband goes or someone else goes to every appointment. After I heard the words, cancer, I didn't hear another word at my first appointment. Good luck and come back here often. We are here for you.
Posts.Title: 45 yr old found a 3cmx1.5cm AnnieeC Janet456

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2013 07:54PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: Don't know if I can help, but I know what you are going through. I had 1.9cm, grade 2 clean Sentinal. Stage 1a. Take a deep breath. This is the hardest part. You will find so much support and wise words here.
Posts.Title: Still feeling a little woozy Alikat123 Alikat123

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2013 02:02PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: I agree ... Get it out ASAP, especially if your surgeon recommends it. Or at least get a second opinion to make you feel better about your decision. You will be totally asleep and won't know anything and will have pain medicine for any pain, I'm sure. As far as your future, not sure what you are asking.....but if it's cosmetic you are worried about, that can be dealt with later. Sometimes a mass can start out benign and end up being cancer down the road. It depends on a lot of things but I wouldn't want to take the chance by leaving it in. Hope this helps. I'm no expert but there's a wealth of information on this site. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Surgery to remove mass. should I do it? soulsilence msphil

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2013 07:25PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: You said it well...Bessie.. I get tired of thinking about it, worrying about it, feeling for it, dreaming about it and on and on. Trying to have a better mind set. My breast surgeon at UNC Chapel Hill Memorial hospital went to New Zealand this month for the summer to teach. He was early 40's, took his family with him. He was a rising star in the field of breast cancer, having taught at M.D. Anderson. He passed away suddenly last week in New Zealand. I am heartbroken. He was one of a kind. Held my hand each time we met and said "I'm always going to take care of you." So you never know what will happen when you step your foot out the door.
Posts.Title: Anyone had cancer lumps in areas that mammos do not reach? glorianna Beesie

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2014 05:14PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: I just wanted to say that there are success stories with someone choosing a bilateral MX.  I don't at all have an "ugly chest"  as ICANDOTHIS  stated for those who have MX.  In fact, you can't see my scars.  had nipple reconstruction and tattoos by Vinny.  My new breasts now look a whole lot better than my natural breasts.  That being said, I would MUCH rather have the old girls back than the diagnosis of cancer.  MX was the right choice for me.   I know the outcome could very well be the same even if I had a lumpectomy, but for me, this is one more piece of emotional arsenal that I needed to help me move forward.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2013 10:02PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: You are at the right place. You will find tons of information and support here. This is the hardest part..the not knowing of what is up ahead. Take a deep breath and come to these boards when you have questions. Bone mets is often times treated as a chronic disease as they are many BC women living with these mets for years. Let us know how you are doing and visit often. We are here for you.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed. j1e1n1a j1e1n1a

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2013 01:17PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: So sorry you are here with us but you will find lots of information and support. Not sure what surgery you are having but they should be able to determine the stage at that time. Once you have a treatment plan, things will make more sense. Take a deep breath and take care of yourself. If you aren't sleeping, ask your doctor for something. If you need something for your anxiety, ask for that. Now is the time to put yourself first and be as healthy as you can be going into surgery. Please keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Protecting implants sbrownrigg sbrownrigg

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2012 10:31AM Obxflygirl1 wrote: Hi Stage 1 Sisters! I have a question for everyone. I just had a bilateral.1.6 cm IDC. Stage 1a er+ pr+. HER 2 neu. My Oncontype score just came back at 17. Dr. Says 11% chance of recurrence in 10 yrs. If I took Chemo, it would drop it to 7%. Small, small, benefit. If any of you have any numbers similar, would you please let me know what you and your doctor decided on chemo? Thanks so much!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2013 05:15PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: I, too, was scared and sick to my stomach when it came time for first post MX shower. I cried like a baby and said I'm not ready. DH guided me through it, waterproofing drains and helping me undress. He looked first as I had my back to the bathroom mirror . He said , "you need to look." It's nothing like you have pictured in your head." He was right. I was so relieved. The TE's were expanded some and the incisions were neat and a lot smaller than I imagined. It's still a lot to process but once you have the first peek, you will be able to move forward. Hang in there. :)
Posts.Title: Seeing Incisions for First Time After Mastectomy danawp cathyann

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2012 08:45PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: I am also 60 and was diagnosed in August. Hang in there...you will be bombarded with more information than your brain can take in. Always have another set of ears with you, I completely missed a lot of stuff my surgeon and oncologist said...before and after surgery. This site is a wealth of information so keep us informed and ask any and all questions. We are here for you.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed HopeFaithCourage Traii

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2014 06:55PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: A lot of woman are not able to keep their nipples. I am one of them. The good news is that the nipple surgery is usually out patient and relatively easy. Then you can get tattooed for the areola or they can make you areolas, I believe. Search this board and you will find all kinds of info. Some girls don't have nipple surgery but have 3-D tattoos for nips and areola and they look amazing. I had the nipple surgery and then tattoos for the finishing touch. I am very happy with the way they turned out.
Posts.Title: Double Masectomy with no Nipples Lillp07 bobogirl

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 05:10PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: Hey girls..... For those of you considering 3D tatoos. Or nipple tats....google Vinnie Myers. He works out of New Orleans and Baltimore and is certified by the National Breast Cancer foundation as a supporter and partner. Work runs around $400 and he will file insurance for you. His photos on his site are amazing. I found out about him on the reconstruction board. Haven't used him but seriously considering ......
Posts.Title: In shock bennymuffins websister

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2014 10:28PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: Gloria ...this is truly the hardest time.  My only advice at the start would be to seek opinions at a NCI facility.  You will find a team of doctors who specialize in breast cancer treatment .  I drove 4 hours to the closest NCI hospital (after reading the same advice on these boards) and I was seen by a breast cancer surgeon, a oncologist and a plastic surgeon in the same appointment. . They worked together during my surgery and treatment.   They offered resources for everything, even discounted hotel rooms for cancer patients.  I still travel 4 hours for my 3 month check ups.    I'm not saying there aren't excellent doctors in other places but it never hurts to seek 2 or even 3 opinions.  You're going to be overwhelmed with information.  Please try to have a second set of ears at your appointments.  I missed half of what was said at every appointment in the beginning. Ask questions on these boards ....you will find valuable information and much support from all of us.  Take a deep breath and know we are here for you.  Sending a big hug your way......
Posts.Title: IDC and I'm so lost glsgls Obxflygirl1

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 09:50PM Obxflygirl1 wrote: Hi, I'm 61, score was 17, no nodes. Oncologist and breast surgeon agreed no chemo. I'm post menopausal and they took that in consideration. The benefit of chemo was very small... I think in my case it was 2%. I'm on Aromasin. My tumor grade was 2. I went to Chapel Hill UNC.
